A black box in the car ?

American road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the decaying Highway-system , and believe they have found the solution in a small black box that can be found on the dashboard of any car .

The devices that record each kilometre travelled and report the information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and the state planning offices to revise the outdated system for financing US roads .
The usually rather boring area of road planning has suddenly sparked intense debate with colourful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups , arguing that the government can use the small boxes to record the kilometres travelled – and perhaps also where they were driven – and then use the information to calculate tax rents .
The Tea Party is appalled .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on how to proceed , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently examining how they can switch over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile .
Thousands of motorists have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS surveillance .
This is really a must for our country .

“ It ’ s not something we ’ ll only possibly use , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Managing Director of Southern California Assn of Governments , who plans to record miles for all California car drivers in the state from 2025 onwards .
The way we pay these taxes will change .
The technology is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed from taxes paid to Americans at the fuel dispenser , is bankrupt .
But there is no longer as much dancing in America as it used to be . is . is . , , , , , , , ,
Cars use less petrol .
The state oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 cents per litre ) has not increased for 20 years .
Politicians do not dare to raise the tax by one cent at high fuel prices .
“ The fuel tax is simply not sustainable , ” Lee Munnich , an expert in traffic legislation at the University of Minnesota .
His state has recently equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a meile-based payment system .
“ This is the most sensible long-term option , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a meile-based user fee .

Not surprisingly , the idea resonates with urban liberals , for example , because the tax could be used to influence driving behaviour in such a way as to reduce congestion and climate-damaging emissions .
California planners rely on the system to develop strategies to achieve the ambitious , legally-anchored goals of the federal state on climate change .
But the Republican Bill Shuster of Pennsylvania , Chairman of the House Transportation Committee , has also stated that he sees it as the most viable long-term alternative .
The free marketers of the Reason Foundation are also inspired by the idea of having drivers pay after a short distance .
“ This is not a tax that disappears in a black hole , ” says Adrian Moore , Vice President for Reason Guidelines .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two former US transport ministers , who , in a 2011 report , called on Congress to move toward meile-based accounting .
Last year , the US Senate approved a $ 90 million pilot project involving 10,000 cars .

But the majority in the House of Representatives blocked the move , responding to the concerns of rural MPs representing people who often have to travel many miles to work or to the city in their daily lives .
Several states and major cities are nevertheless moving in this direction on their own .
The most committed is Oregon , which is currently recruiting 5,000 drivers for the country ’ s largest experiment .
These drivers will soon pay the mileage tax to the state instead of the mineral oil tax .
Nevada has already completed a pilot project .
New York City is also considering this .
Illinois tests it to a limited extent with trucks .

And the I-95 coalition , which includes the transport ministries of 17 states on the east coast ( including Maryland , Pennsylvania , Virginia , and Florida ) , is currently investigating how to introduce the change .
The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where 50 volunteers were recently equipped with the equipment , drivers were skeptical that the government could follow any of its movements .
“ Concerns about Big Brother and such things were a major problem , ” says Alauddin Khan , Head of Strategy and Results Management at the Department of Transportation of Nevada .
People did not want it .
When the test started , the Nevada ACLU on its website warned : “ It would be relatively easy to turn tachographs into full-fledged surveillance devices . ”
There is no need to build a gigantic , bulky technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to collect data about the daily movements of individuals .
Nevada is part of a number of states that are now looking for affordable technology to enable the state to capture miles travelled , but not exactly when and where .
Thus , Khan said , the public would also be more reassured .
Hunting for this technology has led some authorities to a small startup company called True Mileage in California .
The company was originally not set up to help states tax drivers .
Rather , it was its goal to enter an emerging market for car insurance , where drivers are to pay on the basis of the mileage travelled .
But the devices tested by them are also interesting for road planners , because they do not work with GPS and provide only limited information that is regularly uploaded via modem .
“ People are more willing to participate if their speed and locations are not recorded , ” said Ryan Morrison , CEO of True Mileage .
Major mistakes have been made in some of these public pilot programmes .
There are much cheaper and less intrusive ways of doing this .
In Oregon , planners experiment with giving drivers a range of choices .
You can choose a device with or without GPS .
Or they do not choose a unit at all and instead pay a flat rate based on the miles travelled on average by all residents of the state .
Others hope to be able to sell the concept of a suspicious public by providing the equipment with more functions than with less .

In New York City , traffic officials want to develop a tax device that can also pay parking fees , pay insurance only for miles travelled , and collect speed data from other vehicles in real time , allowing drivers to avoid congestion .
“ Drivers would be motivated to participate through the added value of the benefits offered by the system , ” says a city planning document .
Some road planners , however , wonder whether all the talk of paying per mile is not just a huge distraction .

At the Metropolitan Transportation Commission for the area of San Francisco Bay , officials said that Congress could simply solve the problem of the bankrupt Highway Trust Fund by raising fuel taxes .
An additional one-time fee or annual levy could be imposed on drivers with hybrid vehicles or other vehicles that consume little petrol , so that they , too , pay a fair share .
‘ There is no reason for an operation if an aspirin is sufficient ’ , says Randy Rentschler , the Commission ’ s head of legislation and public affairs .

Esa decides on major space missions : Missions for Billions
Remote planets , gravitational waves or black holes - experts from the European Space Agency must now agree on two major projects that they want to launch in the coming years .
30 proposals were available , five are still in the race .
Far worlds .
More than 1000 planets at other stars have already found astronomers .
No one knows whether there is life in at least some of them .
The choice is difficult : should you search for gravitational waves ?
Or rather explore the origin of the cosmos ?
Or search for earth-like planets and discover alien life with it ?
These are the questions raised by those responsible for the European Space Agency , Esa .
For their " Cosmic Vision " programme , they are looking for ideas for two major space projects that are designed to drive research forward .
The budget for such " L missions " is approximately EUR 1 billion each .
The start is expected to be 2028 and 2034 .
In early September , the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions .
30 ideas were under discussion , five of which were now shortlisted .
Many bodies examine the proposals and look at the researchers .
A final decision will be taken by the scientific programme committee in the next few days .
In total , four big questions have been selected by the Esa , to which the missions of the program " Cosmic Vision " launched in 2007 will find answers .
What are the conditions for the emergence of planets and lives ?
The exact processes of the formation of stars from large gas clouds - and thus the formation of planets surrounding these stars - are still in the proverbial dark .
A large infrared telescope in space could penetrate this dark .
And if a star has a planet , under what circumstances can life develop there ?
To address this issue , the " Cheops " space telescope will be launched in 2017 , which will examine more closely 500 known planetary systems in our vicinity .
The possibilities are limited , but Cheops is a small mission with a budget of EUR 150 million .

With larger instruments , astronomers could map Earth like planets and even analyze the composition of their atmospheres , thus searching for " biomarkers " : gases that are considered as an indicator of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This question , too , is ultimately intended to shed light on the conditions for the emergence of life .
The magnetic activity of a star plays an important role and the interaction of its magnetic field and the particle radiation emitted by it with the planetary system .
In our solar system these processes can be investigated in an exemplary manner .
With the Solar Orbiter , the Esa has already approved a M-class mission ( there the budget is around half a billion euros ) for this issue .
The probe is scheduled to launch in 2017 and monitor the surface and activity of the sun .
Jupiter and its moons are of great interest to the researchers .
You want to find out what role the giant planet played in the development of the solar system .
The Esa is the first of the three L missions of the Cosmic Vision program .
The probe " Juice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) starts its journey probably 2022 .
Eight years later , she reaches Jupiter and is to study the atmosphere of the planet as well as the icy moons of Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .
What are the basic physical laws of the universe ?
The universe offers many possibilities to study matter under extreme conditions and to examine whether the laws of nature we know are still valid there .
Perhaps there are also deviations that might lead the physicists to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be united .
How did the universe come into being and what is it ?
13.7 billion years ago our cosmos was created by the big bang .

In addition to the material we are familiar with , from the stars , planets , and living beings like us , there are dark matter , whose gravity holds galaxies and galaxy clusters together , and dark energy , through which the expansion of space accelerates .
So far , researchers do not know which physical laws were valid in the first fractions of the Big Bang , nor what dark matter and dark energy exist .
With " Euclid " Esa has already approved an M mission here , which is scheduled to start in 2020 .

With a special telescope , the probe is supposed to investigate the distribution of matter in the universe for the first time in the entire sky , thus enabling conclusions on the nature of dark matter and dark energy .
Who Can Race
Of the 30 proposals , only two will be left at the end of the selection procedure .
According to many experts , the best chances of being approved as an L-mission are " E-Lisa " , a sophisticated concept for the detection of gravitational waves .
These are physicists ’ changes in the structure of space time that Albert Einstein predicted almost 100 years ago .
They have not been shown up to now .
Elisa could do that , the scientists hope behind the project .
The mission provides for a detector consisting of two or three probes that will be deployed in space .
In contrast to plants on Earth , it could also prove gravitational waves created by the Big Bang , thus providing new insights into the formation of the cosmos .

Four more proposals compete for the second L mission : a large X-ray telescope called " Athena " , which is to explore black holes , " Icy Planets " , another mission to the outer planets of the solar system , " Prism " , a mission to measure cosmic background radiation , and the " Exopplanet Finder " , which is to explore and explore similar planets .
There are already proposals for sample return transport from Mars , for research into moon , Venus and asteroids and for solar physics .

An interesting point is lost in the constant repetition of this ancient history .
Why expect an independent Scotland to dance according to the European pipe ?
Why exchange the London yoke for that of Brussels , especially now ?
These are the real European news : the great post-war plan for uniting Europe has stalled .
With the euro crisis , the European project has officially died .
Across the EU , parties that are hostile to the EU or want to throw the euro out as a common currency are gaining ground .

Even in Germany , the Euroskeptic Alternative for Germany – founded only this year – could win nearly five million votes in the September federal election , effectively driving out the Free Democrats ( the equivalent of the British Liberal Democrats ) from the Bundestag .
There has always been domestic opposition to the plan to create a federal Europe .
The current economic crisis , however , turns out to be a turning point .

Because of the strict austerity imposed by Berlin and the European Central Bank , combined with the straitjacket into which the national economy is coerced by sticking to the single currency , many people believe that the European project has gone too far .
The euro crisis has little to do with national governments causing excessive budget deficits – only in Greece .
Instead , the Eurosystem has pegged its members to exchange rates , which are beneficial to German exporters – and German politicians would like to leave that way .
Without the possibility of devaluation of the local currency , southern Europe finds itself with a built-in productivity disadvantage vis-à-vis Germany .
The only way is to cut wages and public spending – spurred on by Berlin .
Behind the current budget and currency problems lies a deeper European productivity problem .

As a result of the “ green ” energy directives imposed by Brussels – a code for subsidizing French and German energy companies at the expense of consumers – European industry pays twice for electricity and four times for gas compared to the United States .
This is a crippling cost disadvantage , as we have seen in Grangemouth .
All wage fixing in the world does not protect the European petrochemical industry from being pushed into the corner by cheap American shale gas .
As a result , a revolt , especially in France , the EU ’ s former cheerleader .
After the war , France ’ s political elite saw the EU as a vehicle to keep Germany in check and raise Paris on an equal footing with Washington .
But Berlin no longer needs Paris as a gateway to political legitimacy , and has pushed Europe through its own economic policies , which is what the battered French economy is struggling with .

It wants to use the EU elections next year to forge an anti-EU , anti-Community currency bloc in the European Parliament .
If the anti-EU parties perform well in these elections – and this is very possible – then for the first time such a bloc could dominate the European Parliament .
That is the point I want to make : in the not too distant future , the growing resentment against the EU and the single currency will unite to abolish the euro .
The EU will not disappear , but it will become more like the “ Europe of the ( sovereign ) nations ” that General de Gaulle favored .
Germany and a few of its satellite economies may stick to the euro , but France and southern Europe will return to their own currencies .
I expect Britain to distance itself from this project in the hope of being flattered with the US .

Where is Scotland in all this ?

I suspect that Scotland could go very well in a looser European grouping if we retain our own currency .
